description: Borrowed from Dutch ijsberg (compound of ijs (“ice”) +‎ berg (“mountain”)), from Middle Dutch ijsberch. First used to describe a glacier as seen at a distance from a ship then used as a term to describe the floating chunks of ice broken off from such glaciers. Cognate to German Eisberg, Danish isbjerg, Norwegian isberg and Swedish isberg.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The seaward end of a glacier. [18th–19th c.]
A huge mass of ocean-floating ice which has broken off a glacier or ice shelf [from 19th c.]
examples: The Titanic hit an iceberg and sank.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, after an adjective) An impending disastrous event whose adverse effects are only beginning to show, in reference to one-tenth of the volume of an iceberg being visible above water.
